Description: Fragment of broad conical foot of Chian, perhaps Wild Goat Style, pottery vessel, a large chalice or heavy chalice; inside reserved; exterior, white slip; from top of foot: band of alternating lotus flowers and buds separated by dots and with added red, between lines; dot and billet pattern band between lines; band at edge of foot.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The size of the foot suggests that it comes from a large vessel such as a heavy chalice The heavy decoration is however, typical of the Wild Goat Style. The sherd should belong to the end of the period of the Wild Goat Style since the heavy chalice does not normally appear as early as that style, while the thickness and diameter of this sherd suggest that it comes from a vessel much larger than a chalice. Perhaps the sherd marks the transition to the Mature Animal Style.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 213, no. 22)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 100, no. 305.3, pl. XXXII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0409) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4686 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
